segment.source: Sysprep Process Overview
segment.target: Sysprep Process Overview

segment.source: Sysprep Process Overview
segment.target: Sysprep Process Overview

segment.source: Sysprep Process Overview
segment.target: Sysprep Process Overview

segment.source: The System Preparation (Sysprep) tool is used to change Windows® images from a generalized state to a specialized state, and then back to a generalized state.
segment.target: The System Preparation (Sysprep) tool is used to change Windows® images from a generalized state to a specialized state, and then back to a generalized state.

segment.source: A generalized image can be deployed on any computer.
segment.target: A generalized image can be deployed on any computer.

segment.source: A specialized image is targeted to a specific computer.
segment.target: A specialized image is targeted to a specific computer.

segment.source: You must reseal, or generalize, a Windows image before you capture and deploy the image.
segment.target: You must reseal, or generalize, a Windows image before you capture and deploy the image.

segment.source: For example, when you use the Sysprep tool to generalize an image, Sysprep removes all system-specific information and resets the computer.
segment.target: For example, when you use the Sysprep tool to generalize an image, Sysprep removes all system-specific information and resets the computer.

segment.source: The next time that the computer restarts, your customers can add user-specific information through Out-Of-Box Experience (OOBE) and accept the Microsoft Software License Terms.
segment.target: The next time that the computer restarts, your customers can add user-specific information through Out-Of-Box Experience (OOBE) and accept the Microsoft Software License Terms.

segment.source: Sysprep.exe is located in the %WINDIR%system32sysprep directory on all Windows installations.
segment.target: Sysprep.exe is located in the %WINDIR%system32sysprep directory on all Windows installations.

segment.source: If you transfer a Windows image to a different computer, you must run the Sysprep command together with the /generalize option, even if the other computer has the same hardware configuration.
segment.target: If you transfer a Windows image to a different computer, you must run the Sysprep command together with the /generalize option, even if the other computer has the same hardware configuration.

segment.source: The Sysprep /generalize command removes unique information from your Windows installation so that you can reuse that image on a different computer.
segment.target: The Sysprep /generalize command removes unique information from your Windows installation so that you can reuse that image on a different computer.

segment.source: For more information, see Sysprep (Generalize) a Windows installation.
segment.target: For more information, see Sysprep (Generalize) a Windows installation.

segment.source: Sysprep Executable
segment.target: Sysprep Executable

segment.source: Sysprep.exe is the main program that calls other executable files that prepare the Windows installation.
segment.target: Sysprep.exe is the main program that calls other executable files that prepare the Windows installation.

segment.source: Sysprep.exe is located in the %WINDIR%system32sysprep directory on all Windows installations.
segment.target: Sysprep.exe is located in the %WINDIR%system32sysprep directory on all Windows installations.

segment.source: If you use the command line instead of the System Preparation Tool GUI, you must first close the GUI and then run Sysprep from the %WINDIR%system32sysprep directory.
segment.target: If you use the command line instead of the System Preparation Tool GUI, you must first close the GUI and then run Sysprep from the %WINDIR%system32sysprep directory.

segment.source: You must also run Sysprep on the same version of Windows that you used to install Sysprep.
segment.target: You must also run Sysprep on the same version of Windows that you used to install Sysprep.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Beginning with Windows 8.1, the Sysprep user interface is deprecated.
segment.target: Beginning with Windows 8.1, the Sysprep user interface is deprecated.

segment.source: The Sysprep UI will continue to be supported in this release however it may be removed in a future release.
segment.target: The Sysprep UI will continue to be supported in this release however it may be removed in a future release.

segment.source: We recommend that you update your Windows deployment workflow to use the Sysprep command line.
segment.target: We recommend that you update your Windows deployment workflow to use the Sysprep command line.

segment.source: For more information about the Sysprep Command line tool, see Sysprep Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information about the Sysprep Command line tool, see Sysprep Command-Line Options.

segment.source: Sysprep Process Overview
segment.target: Sysprep Process Overview

segment.source: When Sysprep runs, it goes through the following process:
segment.target: When Sysprep runs, it goes through the following process:

segment.source: Sysprep verification.
segment.target: Sysprep verification.

segment.source: Verifies that Sysprep can run.
segment.target: Verifies that Sysprep can run.

segment.source: Only an administrator can run Sysprep.
segment.target: Only an administrator can run Sysprep.

segment.source: Only one instance of Sysprep can run at a time.
segment.target: Only one instance of Sysprep can run at a time.

segment.source: Also, Sysprep must run on the version of Windows that you used to install Sysprep.
segment.target: Also, Sysprep must run on the version of Windows that you used to install Sysprep.

segment.source: Logging initialization.
segment.target: Logging initialization.

segment.source: Initializes logging.
segment.target: Initializes logging.

segment.source: For more information, see Sysprep Log Files.
segment.target: For more information, see Sysprep Log Files.

segment.source: Parsing command-line arguments.
segment.target: Parsing command-line arguments.

segment.source: Parses command-line arguments.
segment.target: Parses command-line arguments.

segment.source: If a user does not provide command-line arguments, a System Preparation Tool window appears and enables users to specify Sysprep actions.
segment.target: If a user does not provide command-line arguments, a System Preparation Tool window appears and enables users to specify Sysprep actions.

segment.source: Processing Sysprep actions.
segment.target: Processing Sysprep actions.

segment.source: Processes Sysprep actions, calls appropriate .dll files and executable files, and adds actions to the log file.
segment.target: Processes Sysprep actions, calls appropriate .dll files and executable files, and adds actions to the log file.

segment.source: Verifying Sysprep processing actions.
segment.target: Verifying Sysprep processing actions.

segment.source: Verifies that all .dll files have processed all their tasks, and then either shuts down or restarts the system.
segment.target: Verifies that all .dll files have processed all their tasks, and then either shuts down or restarts the system.

segment.source: Persisting the Hardware Configuration
segment.target: Persisting the Hardware Configuration

segment.source: If you create an image of this installation for deployment to a different computer, you must run the Sysprep command together with the /generalize option, even if the other computer has the identical hardware configuration.
segment.target: If you create an image of this installation for deployment to a different computer, you must run the Sysprep command together with the /generalize option, even if the other computer has the identical hardware configuration.

segment.source: The Sysprep /generalize command removes unique information from a Windows installation so that you can reuse that image on different computers.
segment.target: The Sysprep /generalize command removes unique information from a Windows installation so that you can reuse that image on different computers.

segment.source: The next time that you boot the Windows image, the specialize configuration pass runs.
segment.target: The next time that you boot the Windows image, the specialize configuration pass runs.

segment.source: If you want to install a Windows image to computers that have the same hardware configuration, you can preserve the device-drivers installation in a Windows image.
segment.target: If you want to install a Windows image to computers that have the same hardware configuration, you can preserve the device-drivers installation in a Windows image.

segment.source: To do this, in your answer file, specify the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting in the Microsoft-Windows-PnPSysprep component.
segment.target: To do this, in your answer file, specify the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting in the Microsoft-Windows-PnPSysprep component.

segment.source: The default value is false.
segment.target: The default value is false.

segment.source: If you set the setting to true, the Plug and Play devices remain on the computer during the generalize configuration pass.
segment.target: If you set the setting to true, the Plug and Play devices remain on the computer during the generalize configuration pass.

segment.source: You do not have to reinstall these devices during the specialize configuration pass.
segment.target: You do not have to reinstall these devices during the specialize configuration pass.

segment.source: For more information, see Use Answer Files with Sysprep and Unattended Windows Setup Reference Guide.
segment.target: For more information, see Use Answer Files with Sysprep and Unattended Windows Setup Reference Guide.

segment.source: Adding Device Drivers
segment.target: Adding Device Drivers

segment.source: Plug and Play devices include modems, sound cards, network adapters, and video cards.
segment.target: Plug and Play devices include modems, sound cards, network adapters, and video cards.

segment.source: The Plug and Play devices on the reference and destination computers do not have to come from the same manufacturer.
segment.target: The Plug and Play devices on the reference and destination computers do not have to come from the same manufacturer.

segment.source: However, you must include the drivers for these devices in the installation.
segment.target: However, you must include the drivers for these devices in the installation.

segment.source: For more information, see Add and Remove Drivers to an Offline Windows Image and Add Device Drivers to Windows During Windows Setup.
segment.target: For more information, see Add and Remove Drivers to an Offline Windows Image and Add Device Drivers to Windows During Windows Setup.

segment.source: Booting to Audit Mode or OOBE
segment.target: Booting to Audit Mode or OOBE

segment.source: When Windows boots, the computer can start in one of two modes:
segment.target: When Windows boots, the computer can start in one of two modes:

segment.source: OOBE
segment.target: OOBE

segment.source: OOBE, also named the out-of-box experience (OOBE), is the first user experience.
segment.target: OOBE, also named the out-of-box experience (OOBE), is the first user experience.

segment.source: The OOBE enables end users to customize their Windows installation.
segment.target: The OOBE enables end users to customize their Windows installation.

segment.source: End users can create user accounts, read and accept the Microsoft® Software License Terms, and select their language and time zones.
segment.target: End users can create user accounts, read and accept the Microsoft® Software License Terms, and select their language and time zones.

segment.source: By default, all Windows installations boot to OOBE first.
segment.target: By default, all Windows installations boot to OOBE first.

segment.source: The oobeSystem configuration pass runs immediately before OOBE starts.
segment.target: The oobeSystem configuration pass runs immediately before OOBE starts.

segment.source: If you do not automatically activate Windows by using a product key, OOBE prompts the user for a product key.
segment.target: If you do not automatically activate Windows by using a product key, OOBE prompts the user for a product key.

segment.source: If the user skips this step during OOBE, Windows reminds the user to enter a valid product key later.
segment.target: If the user skips this step during OOBE, Windows reminds the user to enter a valid product key later.

segment.source: To automatically activate Windows by using a product key, specify a valid product key in the Microsoft-Windows-Shell-SetupProductKey unattend setting during the specialize configuration pass.
segment.target: To automatically activate Windows by using a product key, specify a valid product key in the Microsoft-Windows-Shell-SetupProductKey unattend setting during the specialize configuration pass.

segment.source: For more information, see Work with Product Keys and Activation.
segment.target: For more information, see Work with Product Keys and Activation.

segment.source: Audit Mode
segment.target: Audit Mode

segment.source: If you are running a computer in audit mode to configure the installation to boot to OOBE, either use the Sysprep GUI or run the Sysprep /oobe command.
segment.target: If you are running a computer in audit mode to configure the installation to boot to OOBE, either use the Sysprep GUI or run the Sysprep /oobe command.

segment.source: To prepare a computer for an end user, you must configure the computer to boot to OOBE when an end user starts the computer for the first time.
segment.target: To prepare a computer for an end user, you must configure the computer to boot to OOBE when an end user starts the computer for the first time.

segment.source: In a default Windows installation, OOBE starts after installation is completed, but you can skip OOBE and boot directly to audit mode to customize images.
segment.target: In a default Windows installation, OOBE starts after installation is completed, but you can skip OOBE and boot directly to audit mode to customize images.

segment.source: You can configure Windows to boot directly to audit mode by using the Microsoft-Windows-Deployment | Reseal | Mode setting in an answer file.
segment.target: You can configure Windows to boot directly to audit mode by using the Microsoft-Windows-Deployment | Reseal | Mode setting in an answer file.

segment.source: In audit mode, the computer processes settings in an unattended answer file in the auditSystem and auditUser configuration passes.
segment.target: In audit mode, the computer processes settings in an unattended answer file in the auditSystem and auditUser configuration passes.

segment.source: Audit mode enables you to add customizations to Windows images.
segment.target: Audit mode enables you to add customizations to Windows images.

segment.source: Audit mode does not require that you apply settings in OOBE.
segment.target: Audit mode does not require that you apply settings in OOBE.

segment.source: By bypassing OOBE, you can access the desktop more quickly and perform your customizations.
segment.target: By bypassing OOBE, you can access the desktop more quickly and perform your customizations.

segment.source: You can add more device drivers, install applications, and test the validity of the installation.
segment.target: You can add more device drivers, install applications, and test the validity of the installation.

segment.source: For more information, see:
segment.target: For more information, see:

segment.source: Audit Mode Overview
segment.target: Audit Mode Overview

segment.source: Boot Windows to Audit Mode or OOBE
segment.target: Boot Windows to Audit Mode or OOBE

segment.target: How Configuration Passes Work

segment.source: Detecting the State of a Windows Image
segment.target: Detecting the State of a Windows Image

segment.source: You can use Sysprep to identify the state of a Windows image.
segment.target: You can use Sysprep to identify the state of a Windows image.

segment.source: That is, you can determine whether the image will boot to audit mode or OOBE, or if the image is still in the process of installation.
segment.target: That is, you can determine whether the image will boot to audit mode or OOBE, or if the image is still in the process of installation.

segment.source: For more information, see Windows Setup Installation Process.
segment.target: For more information, see Windows Setup Installation Process.

segment.source: Sysprep Log Files
segment.target: Sysprep Log Files

segment.source: The Sysprep tool logs Windows Setup actions in different directories, depending on the configuration pass.
segment.target: The Sysprep tool logs Windows Setup actions in different directories, depending on the configuration pass.

segment.source: Because the generalize configuration pass deletes certain Windows Setup log files, the Sysprep tool logs generalize actions outside the standard Windows Setup log files.
segment.target: Because the generalize configuration pass deletes certain Windows Setup log files, the Sysprep tool logs generalize actions outside the standard Windows Setup log files.

segment.source: The following table shows the different log file locations that Sysprep uses.
segment.target: The following table shows the different log file locations that Sysprep uses.

segment.source: Item
segment.target: Item

segment.source: Log Path
segment.target: Log Path

segment.source: Generalize
segment.target: Generalize

segment.source: %WINDIR%\System32\Sysprep\Panther
segment.target: %WINDIR%\System32\Sysprep\Panther

segment.source: Specialize
segment.target: Specialize

segment.source: %WINDIR%\Panther\
segment.target: %WINDIR%\Panther\

segment.source: Unattended Windows Setup actions
segment.target: Unattended Windows Setup actions

segment.source: %WINDIR%\Panther\Unattendgc
segment.target: %WINDIR%\Panther\Unattendgc

segment.source: For more information, see Deployment Troubleshooting and Log Files.
segment.target: For more information, see Deployment Troubleshooting and Log Files.

segment.source: Creating and Using Sysprep Providers
segment.target: Creating and Using Sysprep Providers

segment.source: Independent software vendors (ISVs) and independent hardware vendors (IHVs) can create Sysprep providers that enable their applications to support imaging and deployment scenarios.
segment.target: Independent software vendors (ISVs) and independent hardware vendors (IHVs) can create Sysprep providers that enable their applications to support imaging and deployment scenarios.

segment.source: If an application does not currently support generalize operations by using the Sysprep tool, you can create a provider that removes all software-specific and hardware-specific information from the application.
segment.target: If an application does not currently support generalize operations by using the Sysprep tool, you can create a provider that removes all software-specific and hardware-specific information from the application.

segment.source: To create a Sysprep provider, you must do the following:
segment.target: To create a Sysprep provider, you must do the following:

segment.source: Determine which configuration pass (cleanup, generalize, or specialize) your Sysprep provider addresses.
segment.target: Determine which configuration pass (cleanup, generalize, or specialize) your Sysprep provider addresses.

segment.source: Create the appropriate entry point for your Sysprep provider, based on your choice of configuration pass.
segment.target: Create the appropriate entry point for your Sysprep provider, based on your choice of configuration pass.

segment.source: Register the Sysprep provider for use by the Sysprep tool.
segment.target: Register the Sysprep provider for use by the Sysprep tool.

segment.source: Test your Sysprep provider to validate that the provider functions correctly.
segment.target: Test your Sysprep provider to validate that the provider functions correctly.

segment.source: Make sure that you review the log files for warnings and errors.
segment.target: Make sure that you review the log files for warnings and errors.

segment.source: For more information about Sysprep providers, see the System Preparation (Sysprep) Tool Provider Developer’s Guide.
segment.target: For more information about Sysprep providers, see the System Preparation (Sysprep) Tool Provider Developer’s Guide.
